135.01 COMPOSITION.
   In addition to the Chief of Police, the Police Department shall consist of
such officers and other personnel as are appointed from time to time by
Council.
(Ord. 28-10. Passed 4-5-76.)
135.02 APPOINTMENTS.
   (a)   Probationary Period. Each full-time police officer shall be appointed
to his or her position by Council, upon recommendation of the Chief of Police
and the Mayor. Such appointment shall be a probationary one and shall consist
of a term of six (6) months. During such initial probationary term, the police
officer shall serve at the discretion of Council and may, at any time, be
dismissed and discharged from his or her position as a full-time police
officer.
   (b)   Lateral Transfer.
      (1)   The Village of North Kingsville hereby creates a lateral transfer
list for the position of full-time officers for the Village of North Kingsville
Police Department. The Council may hire an individual for the position of full-
time patrolman from the lateral transfer list.
      (2)   The following minimum qualifications are first required to submit
an application:
         A.   Must possess current and valid OPOTA Certification or OPOTA
Letter of Training Equivalency.
         B.   Must be currently employed as a full-time law enforcement officer
as defined by Ohio R.C. Section 2901.01 or laid off from such a position within
the year prior to your application and have a minimum of two (2) consecutive
years of full-time law enforcement experience.
         C.   Must be at least twenty-one (21) years of age, have attained a
high school diploma, or G.E.D.
         D.   Must possess a valid Ohio driver's license and have an acceptable
driving record at time of employment.
         E.   Must pass a thorough background investigation and any and all
other tests required by the Council.
      (3)   Lateral applicant appointed to full-time position of patrolman
shall be placed at pay rate commensurate with his/her current years of full-
time experience.
      (4)   Lateral applicant appointed to full-time position of patrolman
shall receive vacation accrual commensurate with his/her current years of full-
time experience.
      (5)   Lateral applicant appointed to full-time position of patrolman may
receive credit for unused accumulated sick leave earned from another public
entity however this credited time shall not be calculated toward sick time buy
back at time of retirement.
      (6)   The Village of North Kingsville may waive the ninety (90)-day
probationary period to allow the lateral applicant to be entitled to health
insurance upon commencement of a full-time position.
         (Ord. O-21-053. Passed 10-26-21.)
135.03 DISMISSALS.
   Nothing contained in this chapter shall in any way affect the right of
Council or the Mayor to dismiss and discharge any full-time police officer from
his or her position as a full-time police officer in accordance with the Ohio
Revised Code.
(Ord. 143.4. Passed 3-3-75.)
135.04  ABSENCE OF CHIEF OF POLICE.
   (a)    In the absence of the Chief of Police, the Sergeant shall command the
Police Department and shall perform all duties of the Chief of Police,
including preservation of order and discipline and requiring strict compliance
with the ordinances of the Village and the rules and regulations of the
Department.
(Ord. 28.11. Passed 4-5-76.)
   (b)    With authorization from the Mayor, the senior officer in charge shall
receive additional compensation as determined from time to time by Council.
(Res. R-99-001. Passed 1-4-99.)
135.045 COMPENSATORY TIME FOR CHIEF OF POLICE.
   As compensation for holidays worked, the Chief of Police shall receive an
equal number of hours off work, as long as the compensatory time is taken
within six months of the holiday.
(Res. R-99-001. Passed 1-4-99.)
135.05 HOURS OF WORK.
   The Chief of Police and full time police officers shall devote a minimum of
eighty hours, in a fourteen day period, to their duties, plus hours required
for emergency duty.
(Ord. O-19-027. Passed 7-1-19.)
   
135.06 OVERTIME.
   (a)    Officers of the Police Department shall receive one and one-half
times their regular compensation for time worked over eighty hours per fourteen
day period. Upon authorization, in writing, by the Mayor, overtime shall be
paid.
(Ord. O-19-031. Passed 7-1-19.)
   (b)    No overtime shall be required of the Chief of Police unless it is
related to State or Federal grant funds and paid therefrom.
(Res. R-99-001. Passed 1-4-99.)
135.07 CALLOUT PAY.
   The Sergeant and patrolmen shall receive one and one-half times their
regular rate of compensation for callout time when such time worked is over
forty hours in any one work week. A work week is based on a calendar week
basis. Callout time shall be paid after written verification and approval by
the Mayor on the monthly time sheets.
(Ord. 143.241. Passed 4-7-80.)
135.08 CLOTHING ALLOWANCE.
   (a)   Each full-time police officer shall be entitled to a clothing
allowance not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year.
   (b)   Each part-time police officer shall be entitled to a clothing
allowance not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) per year.
   (c)   Each reserve police officer shall be entitled to a clothing allowance
not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per year.
   (d)   Commencing April 1, 2023, all clothing allowances of the Police
Department shall be reported as additional compensation for payroll purposes.
(Ord. O-23-002. Passed 3-15-23.)
135.09 WORKERS' COMPENSATION.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to enter into a contract with the Industrial
Commission of Ohio, Bureau of Workers' Compensation, and to take all steps and
procedures necessary thereto, in order to obtain benefits payable by the
Industrial Commission of Ohio under a workers' compensation program for members
of the Police Department.
(Ord. 964. Passed 12-23-70.)
135.10 REIMBURSEMENT FOR EXPENSES OF FALSE-ALARMS.
   (a)    The Village considers it to be the responsibility of the users of
security systems to pay the cost of responding to an excessive number of false
alarms.
   (b)    An excessive number of false alarms is considered to be whenever four
or more false alarms are set off in any ninety consecutive day period.
   (c)    Users of security systems which cause an excessive number of false
alarms shall reimburse the Village for its expenses in responding to such
alarms as follows:
      (1)    For four to seven false alarms in any ninety consecutive day
period, the user shall pay the Village a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each
excessive false alarm.
      (2)    For eight or more false alarms in any ninety consecutive day
period, the user shall pay the Village a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
for each excessive false alarm. (Ord. O-89-016. Passed 4-3-89.)
135.11 STUN GUN POLICY. (REPEALED)
   (a)    (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
135.11 was repealed by Ordinance O-19-028, passed July 1, 2019.)
   (b)    The Police Chief shall verify that any police officer for the Village
who is issued a "stun gun" for use while on duty as a police officer for the
Village has reviewed such policy and procedure and made himself or herself
completely familiar with the requirements thereof.
(Res. R91-010. Passed 5-6-91.)
135.12 POLICE ENFORCEMENT AND EDUCATION FUND.
   (a)    A special revenue fund is hereby created that shall be referred to as
the "Police Enforcement and Education Fund."
   (b)    The Clerk-Treasurer shall deposit into said Fund all portions of
fines received by the Village of North Kingsville from courts having
jurisdiction in the Village of North Kingsville for violations of Ohio R.C.
4511.19(A) and Section
 333.01(a) of these Codified Ordinances.
   (c)    This Fund shall be used by the Village of North Kingsville Police
Department solely to pay costs incurred in enforcing Ohio R.C. 4611.19 and
Section
 333.01(a) of these Codified Ordinances and for the purpose of educating the
public about laws governing operation of a motor vehicle while under the
influence of alcohol, the dangers of operating a motor vehicle while under the
influence of alcohol and other information relating to the operation of a motor
vehicle and consumption of alcoholic beverages.
(Res. R-91-002. Passed 4-1-91.)

137.01  COMPOSITION; OFFICERS.
   The Fire Department shall consist of one Fire Chief and such other officers
and personnel as determined from time to time by Council. The Department shall,
at its first meeting in April of each year, elect from its members one
Assistant Chief, one Secretary and one Treasurer, and it may, by its bylaws or
rules, create such other duties as it may desire.
137.02 APPOINTMENTS; TERM OF OFFICE OF FIRE CHIEF.
   (a)    The Fire Chief and members of the Fire Department shall be appointed
by the Mayor with the consent of Council. The Fire Chief shall hold his or her
office for a term of two years and until his or her successor is appointed and
qualified.
(Ord. 1022. Passed 5-1-72.)
   (b)    The appointment of any person as a member of the Fire Department and
the Volunteer Fire Department Rescue Squad shall be contingent upon the
approval of a majority of the members of Council.
(Ord. 143.409. Passed 3-5-84.)
137.025 RESIDENCE OF FIRE CHIEF.
   During the entire term of service as Fire Chief of the Village, the person
filling said position shall be required to be a resident of the Village,
effective as of the passage date of this section.
(Ord. O-90-044. Passed 11-6-90.)
137.03 DUTIES OF FIRE CHIEF.
   (a)    The Fire Chief shall have command over all members of the Fire
Department and all other persons who may be present at fires, and shall have
police power at all fires.
   (b)    The Fire Chief shall examine into the condition of all apparatus
belonging to the Village and used for the purposes of the Fire Department, as
often as the circumstances render it expedient or when directed to do so by
resolution of Council. Whenever any building or apparatus used for the purposes
of the Department requires an alteration, addition or repair, the Chief shall
report the same, in writing, to Council, with an estimate of the cost hereof.
   (c)    The Fire Chief shall receive all returns by officers of the company
and all communications relating to the Department, and shall keep an accurate
roll of the company, specifying the time of the admission and discharge and the
age of each member, all of which he or she shall report, in writing, to Council
annually or when required by resolution of Council.
   (d)    He or she shall also report all accidents by fire which happen in the
Village, with the cause thereof, as well as can be ascertained, and the number
of buildings destroyed or damaged, as near as can be ascertained, together with
the names of the owners or occupants thereof.
 
   (e)    He or she shall at least once every year, report to Council a
complete, detailed inventory of all property pertaining to the Department and
owned by the Village, with the condition and the estimated value thereof.
   (f)    The Fire Chief, or the Assistant Chief acting as Chief (in the
absence of the Chief), as soon as any fire is out or under control shall order
all members of the company to their quarters, except a sufficient number to
guard and protect the property and surrounding premises.
(Ord. 1022. Passed 5-1-72.)
137.04  DUTIES OF ASSISTANT CHIEF.
   (a)    The Assistant Chief shall command the Fire Department and shall see
that the apparatus committed to the care of the Department, the building in
which it is deposited and all things in and belonging to the same are kept
neat, clean and in order for immediate use.
   (b)    The Assistant Chief shall preserve order and discipline at all times,
shall require strict compliance with the ordinances of the Village and the
rules and regulations of the Department and shall report annually and as often
as required, in writing, to the Fire Chief, such facts as the Fire Chief is
required to report to Council.
(Ord. 1022. Passed 5-1-72.)
137.05 ABSENCE OF FIRE CHIEF.
   In the absence of the Fire Chief, the officer in charge shall take command
and have all the powers and perform all the duties of the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 1022. Passed 5-1-72.)
137.055 VACANCY IN OFFICE OF FIRE CHIEF.
   (a)    Upon a vacancy in the position of Fire Chief in the Fire Department
of the Village, and prior to the Mayor making an appointment of a replacement
Fire Chief, the members of the Fire Department of the Village shall elect, by
majority ballot, a nominee to the position of Fire Chief
   (b)    Upon the members of the Fire Department of the Village electing a
nominee to the position of Fire Chief, it shall be the responsibility of the
highest ranking officer of the Fire Department to provide the name of the
nominee to the Police and Fire Committee of the Village forthwith.
(Ord. O-91-011. Passed 5-6-91.)
137.06 DUTIES OF SECRETARY.
   The Secretary shall keep all the records of the Fire Department; shall keep
an accurate roll of all the members, stating their names and the date of their
admission and discharge; shall draw all orders upon the Treasurer and keep an
accurate account thereof; and shall perform such other duties as the bylaws of
the Department require.
(Ord. 1022. Passed 5-1-72.)
137.07  DUTIES OF TREASURER.
   The Treasurer shall receive all funds belonging to the Fire Department and
disburse the same only upon the vote of the Department, countersigned by the
Fire Chief; shall keep full and accurate books of account thereof, showing of
whom received and to whom paid, and, at the expiration of his or her term,
shall turn over to his or her successor all books, papers and moneys pertaining
to his or her office.
(Ord. 1022. Passed 5-1-72.)
137.08 BYLAWS; FINES; SUSPENSION OR EXPULSION OF MEMBERS.
   The Fire Department may make such bylaws as it deems best, provided that
such bylaws shall not take effect until submitted to and approved by Council,
may provide for the collection of reasonable fines for nonattendance at
meetings and at fires, and may provide for suspension or expulsion of members
for nonperformance of duty.
(Ord. 1022. Passed 5-1-72)
137.09 LIABILITY OF MEMBERS; PURCHASES.
   No officer or member of the Fire Department, except the Fire Chief, shall
incur any liability for the Department to be paid by the Village, except by the
authority of Council, and the Fire Chief shall not incur any liability to be
paid by Council except in case of urgent necessity or when directed by Council.
All supplies for the Department shall be purchased by the Fire Chief after
having authority from Council to do so.
(Ord. 1022. Passed 5-1-72.)
137.10 HOUSING OF TRUCKS AND EQUIPMENT.
   Council shall provide suitable quarters for housing fire trucks and
equipment.
(Ord. 1022. Passed 5-1-72.)
137.105 PRIVATE TOW-AWAY ZONE.
   There is hereby established a private tow-away zone, as defined in Ohio R.C.
4513.60, for each of the parking lots at the two fire stations in the Village.
(Ord. O-02-007. Passed 3-4-02.)
137.11 FIRE SAFETY INSPECTORS.
   The position of Fire Safety Inspector is hereby established in accordance
with former Ohio R.C. Section 3303.07 and Section 4765.55. A certificate is
required in accordance with Ohio R.C. Section 3737.34.
(Ord. O-22-025. Passed 6-6-22.)
137.12  WORKERS' COMPENSATION.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to enter into a contract with the Industrial
Commission of Ohio, Bureau of Workers' Compensation, and to take all steps and
procedures necessary thereto, in order to obtain benefits payable by the
Industrial Commission of Ohio under a workers' compensation program for members
of the Fire Department.
(Ord. 963. Passed 12-23-70.)
137.13 RESCUE SERVICE FEES.
   (a)    All residents of the Village shall receive rescue service to any
hospital in the County at no cost.
   (b)    All employees of commercial and industrial businesses located in the
Village shall receive rescue service to any hospital in the County at no cost.
(Ord. 142.259. Passed 6-2-80.)
   (c)    Residents shall not be charged for any rescue service in the County
and shall not be charged for emergency transfers outside the County. For
nonemergency calls, residents shall pay a sum, per mile, one way, as determined
from time to time by Council.
(Ord. 143.488. Passed 12-9-85.)
   (d)    The following fees shall be charged for rescue services, effective as
of January 1, 2003:
Code        New Rate
BLS-NON-ER  $300.00
BLS-ER      300.00
ALS1-NON-ER 400.00
ALS1-ER     400.00
ALS2-ER     475.00
ALS-Mileage 5.50
BLS-Mileage 5.50
 
    (Res. O-02-084. Passed 12-18-02.)
   (e)   The policy of the Village collection and write off of accounts
receivable for the rescue services performed by the Fire Department, Rescue
Division, of the Village shall be as follows:
   Any accounts receivable for rescue services that are over six months old and
total less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for which no current address can
be established with reasonable diligence for the debtor shall be written off.
(Ord. O-04-002. Passed 2-2-04.)
 
   (f)   Commencing on March 1, 2009, eighty percent (80%) proceeds received
for rescue services provided by the Fire Department shall be placed in the
General Fund; and, the remaining twenty percent (20%) shall remain in the
Rescue Fund.
(Res. R-09-007. Passed 2-2-09.)
137.135 REIMBURSEMENT OF EMERGENCY MEDICAL TRAINING EXPENSES FOR RESCUE SQUAD
PERSONNEL.
   (a)    Available funds shall be used for purposes of reimbursing members of
the rescue squad for training in emergency medical techniques.
 
   (b)    Such reimbursement shall be in the amount of fifty percent of the
cost of such training after six months of service has been completed after such
training, and fifty percent of such cost after one year of service has been
completed after such training.
(Res. R-94-022. Passed 6-6-94.)
137.137 PAYMENT OF COSTS OF TRAINING FIRE AND RESCUE PERSONNEL; REIMBURSEMENT
POLICY.
   (a)   The Village of North Kingsville shall pay the cost of each member of
the Village of North Kingsville Fire Department for Basic Fire and Basic EMT
training on their first attempt at passing said training and a retaking of said
training at least two years after the initial taking of the course.
(Res. R-15-062. Passed 11-2-15.)
 
   (b)   The Village shall pay the cost of training fire and rescue personnel
for the Village, provided that such personnel agree to repay the cost of said
training to the Village in the event that they do not remain in the employ of
the Village fire or rescue squad for at least two years following the
completion of said training.
(Res. R-98-009. Passed 1-21-98.)
137.14 REIMBURSEMENT FOR EMERGENCY AND NON- EMERGENCY RUNS.
   The Village shall reimburse the Fire Department the sum of three thousand
dollars ($3,000) annually for all emergency and non-emergency runs, payable in
quarterly installments of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ord. 13-089. Passed 12-18-13.)
137.15 FALSE FIRE ALARMS.
   Commencing January 1, 1992, the Village shall charge a building owner or
tenant the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each false fire alarm in
excess of three false fire alarms in any ninety-day period. Said charges shall
be billed and received by the Clerk-Treasurer and placed in an appropriate
account for the use of the Fire Department.
(Res. R-92-006. Passed 1-6-92.)

139.02 OVERTIME.
   (a)    The Street Commissioner shall be paid time and one-half for any hours
worked over forty hours per week when the Mayor verifies and approves such
overtime in writing.
   (b)    All Street Department employees shall be paid time and one-half for
any hours worked over forty hours per week when the Street Commissioner
declares such work to be necessary because of emergency conditions.
(Ord. O-88-060. Passed 12-19-88.)
   (c)    For the purpose of determining whether or not overtime pay is due,
paid holiday hours and paid vacation hours occurring during a specified week
shall be considered as included, with the actual hours worked by an employee
during such week, in the total hours worked in that week.
(Ord. O-89-047. Passed 12-4-89.)

worked when the Mayor verifies and approves the overtime in writing.
(Res. R-99-002. Passed 1-4-99.)

temporary foreman, with additional compensation to be determined from time to
time by Council.

($1,125.00) for thirty (30) foot culvert pipe and one thousand five hundred
($1,500.00) for forty (40) foot culvert pipe. The owner is responsible for
providing the culvert pipe.

145.01 PREFACE, AMENDMENT OF RULES, AND OBJECTIVES.
145.01.1 HOW TO USE THIS DOCUMENT.
   This document for employees of the Village of North Kingsville serves two
purposes:
   (a)   *A summary of personnel policies and practices, benefits,
responsibilities and opportunities available to you as an employee;
   (b)   *An official document governing the personnel administration of all
employees of the Village with references to the Ohio Revised Code and other
administrative orders and resolutions.
   All employees will be provided a copy of the document. It is required that
all employees take time to go over this document and make sure they are aware
of its contents and how it applies. Employees may then wish to keep this
document at work where they can refer to it as the need may arise. From time to
time this document will be updated. It is recommended that any changes received
be immediately included in the employee's copy of the document to avoid any
misunderstandings.
   If an employee has a question or a problem regarding a specific policy,
benefit, or practice, the discussion of it can be found by referring to the
Table of Contents in the front of this document or by looking up the content
area in the index at the end. These statements are written in a manner designed
to apply generally to all full-time, part-time and/or seasonal employees. In
some cases, an employee may want details or information, which was not included
in this document for the sake of brevity. A complete set of all source
documents can be made available to all employees at any time. Additional
references to specific job responsibilities and operating procedures may be
contained in the separate "Standard Operating Procedures" document designed for
various departments.
   If there is a question regarding a written policy, it should be directed to
the department head. If there should be, at any time, any conflict between the
summary in this document and the source material, the reference or source
material, which is current at the time, is the official statement.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.2 PURPOSE.
   It is the purpose of these Rules and Regulations to implement the provisions
of the Ohio Revised Code and Village personnel ordinances and resolutions by
establishing standards and procedures. These regulations are also provided as a
guideline to be followed when a situation occurs which is not specifically
considered in the Ohio Revised Code or personnel resolutions. The Council
reserve all rights authorized to them by the Ohio Revised Code for personnel
administration.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.3 AMENDMENTS.
   Amendments to these Personnel Rules and Regulations shall be made by the
Council. The Council may consult with the various department and division heads
or other knowledgeable persons prior to making recommendations and amendments.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.4 ADMINISTRATION.
   The Mayor or appropriate appointing authority shall be charged with applying
the provisions of this chapter to provide for the orderly conduct of dealing
effectively with the employees of the Village in its pursuit to serve its
citizens efficiently.
   The following provisions of this chapter are hereby adopted and enacted as
part of the Personnel Regulations of the Village, in accordance with the
relevant sections of federal and State law.
   The intention of the Village in establishing the provisions of this chapter
is to provide for employees' benefits and responsibilities in order to promote
better development of services to the public.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.5 ADMINISTRATIVE ORDERS AND BARGAINING AGREEMENTS.
   Nothing contained in these rules shall prohibit the promulgation of
department work rules, standing orders, general orders, or other instructions
either oral or written. However, when in conflict, the more definite shall
apply. To the extent that contractual obligations exist, these Personnel Rules
and Regulations shall provide details where said documents are silent, but
shall not supersede negotiated contract obligations or legal requirements
relating to personnel rules and practices. Contract obligations will apply to
the appropriate bargaining unit only.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.6 POSITIONS COVERED.
   All full-time, part-time and seasonal employees of the Village of North
Kingsville shall be supplied a copy of these Policies and Procedures. All newly
appointed employees shall be given a copy of these Policies and Procedures at
the time of their appointment.
   Any amendment to these Policies and Procedures shall be made available to
the employees in writing or through means deemed appropriate by the Council. It
shall be the obligation of each employee to read and become familiar with these
rules.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.7 CLASSIFICATION.
   The official name of the classification of positions for an individual
position shall be known as the "Classification". It shall be used as applicable
including and not limited to any announcement of competitive examinations.
Nothing herein shall preclude the use of a generic title if the Village chooses
to use a jointly administered selection procedure.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.8 INTERPRETATION.
   The policies are intended to cover most personnel problems and actions,
which arise. The Council shall interpret those not specifically covered. Such
interpretations shall be in concert with the spirit and letter of Section
 145.01.2 - Purpose.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.9 DELEGATION.
   The Council may delegate such duties and functions as they deem appropriate.
The Village Clerk may be designated to perform certain personnel record-keeping
functions.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.10 MERIT SYSTEM.
   In the application of the merit system, employees and applicants shall be
evaluated solely on merit without regard to race, sex, religion, disability,
national origin, or any factor precluded by applicable law.
   These policies and procedures provide for the recruitment, selection,
training, evaluation and retention of the best employee for each position in
the Village of North Kingsville. They provide for the orderly establishment of
procedures for personnel administration which are consistent with the following
merit principles;
   (a)    Recruiting, selecting, and advancing employees on the basis of their
relative ability, knowledge, and skills, including open competition of
qualified applicants for initial appointment, where appropriate;
   (b)    Establishing pay rates consistent with the principle of providing
comparable pay for comparable work;
   (c)    Training employees, as needed, to assure high quality performance;
   (d)    Retaining employees on the basis of their satisfactory performance;
correcting unsatisfactory performance and separating employees whose
unsatisfactory performance cannot be corrected;
   (e)    Assuring fair treatment of applicants and employees in all aspects of
personnel administration without regard to political affiliation, handicap,
race, color, age, national origin, citizenship, sex, or religion;
   (f)    Assuring that employees are protected against coercion from partisan,
political purposes and are prohibited from using their official authority for
the purpose of interfering with or affecting the results of an election or a
nomination for office.
      (Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.11 EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER/AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT.
   The Village shall implement these policies in accordance with the letter and
spirit of federal, state, and local laws and regulations prohibiting
discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin,
citizenship, sex, age, and disability, both in the employment and supervision
of Village employees.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.12 DISCLAIMER.
   Information included in these personnel policies and procedures,
classification plan, compensation plan, and performance evaluation system are
not to be considered a contract and may be changed by the Council without
notice.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.13 SEVERABILITY CLAUSE.
   If sections of these policies and procedures are held invalid, the remaining
sections shall not be affected and shall remain in effect.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.14 REPEALER.
   Any prior ordinances, resolutions, memorandum, or other written documents in
conflict with these policies and procedures are hereby repealed. All oral
statements past, present, and future in conflict with these policies and
procedures are invalid.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.15 MANAGERIAL RIGHTS.
   Any employee may be transferred from one department to another as long as he
or she is assigned to basically the same type and level of work. Transfers may
be either temporary or permanent in order to meet the needs of the Village.
Transfers may also be made at the request of the employee in order to provide
the employee with new supervision and experience.
   The Village reserves the right and authority to administer the business of
the Village, direct its operations, promulgate rules and regulations and to
otherwise exercise the prerogatives of management, more particularly including:
   (a)    To manage and direct its employees, including the right to select,
hire, promote, transfer, assign, evaluate, layoff, recall, reprimand, suspend,
demote, discharge or discipline, and to maintain order among employees;
   (b)    To manage and determine the location, type and number of physical
facilities, equipment, programs, and the work to be performed;
   (c)    To determine the Village's goals, objectives, programs, services and
budget and to utilize personnel and technology in a manner designed to
effectively meet these purposes;
   (d)    To determine the size and composition of the work force and the
employer's organizational structure, including the right to relieve employees
from duty by layoff or job abolishment;
   (e)    To determine the hours of work and work schedules and to establish
the necessary work rules for all employees;
   (f)    To determine when a job vacancy exists, what duties are to be
included in all job classifications, and what standards of quality and
performance are to be maintained;
   (g)    To maintain the security of records and other pertinent information;
   (h)    To determine and implement necessary actions in emergency situations.
      (Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.16 NOTICE.
   The Village of North Kingsville Council, at its option, may change, delete,
suspend or discontinue any part or parts of the policies in this document at
any time without prior notice. Any such action shall apply to existing as well
as future employees with continued employment being the consideration between
the employer and employee. Employees may not accrue eligibility for monetary
benefits (provided for in writing) that they have not earned through actual
time spent at work. Employees shall not accrue eligibility for any benefits,
rights, or privileges beyond the last day worked. No one other than the Council
may alter or modify any of the policies in this document. No statement or
promise by a supervisor, manager, or department head may be interpreted as a
change in policy nor will it constitute an agreement with an employee.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.01.17 DEFINITIONS.
   “Active Pay Status” includes time on duty, vacation leave, sick leave,
holidays, and other paid leave.
   “Appeal” means the response of an employee to the decision made based on a
disciplinary action.
   “Appointing Authority” means the person or agency that, based on the Ohio
Revised Code, has the authority to employ persons to perform the required
duties of the office or agency. Included is the companion authority to dismiss,
promote and other normal activities.
   “Classification” means a group of positions that involve similar duties and
responsibilities, require similar qualifications, and which are properly
designated by a common descriptive title indicating the general nature of the
work. A class may include only one position in some circumstances.
   “Discipline” means an action taken against an employee by the supervisor or
management as the result of an employee's lack of adherence to rules and
procedures of the organization and the community.
   “Exempt Employee” means employees not covered by the Fair Labor Standards
Act (FLSA) overtime provisions and do not receive either pay or compensatory
time in lieu of overtime pay.
   “Employer” means the Council, or the designee of the Council specifically
authorized to make policy decisions on their behalf.
   “Full Time Employee” means an employee who works a minimum of 40 hours in a
standard workweek.
   “Grievance” means an action initiated by an employee concerning work rules,
policies, or procedures.
   “Immediate Family”. The immediate family of an employee includes the
employee's spouse, child, parent, grandparent, brother or sister, mother or
father in-law, son or daughter in- law, as well as step-son, stepdaughter,
step-mother, step-father, step-brother, and step-sister.
   “Non-Exempt Employee” means employees who are covered by the Fair Labor
Standards Act (FLSA) overtime provisions, and can receive pay or compensatory
time in lieu of overtime pay.
   “Part Time Employee” means an employee who works less than 40 hours in a
standard workweek.
   “Personnel Policies and Procedures” means the rules and regulations
governing the day to day relationships between employer and employee, and which
explain the privileges, benefits, and rights of the employee as well as the
responsibilities of the employer.
   “Probationary Period” means the period of time at the beginning of
employment or following a promotion which constitutes a trial period for the
employee in order to ascertain his or her suitability.
   “Safety Personnel” means uniformed employees in the Police and Fire
Departments.
   “Seasonal or Temporary Employee” means an employee working for a brief
period of time or on a specified project that has a termination date.
   “Supervisor” means an individual who has been authorized by the Village
Council to oversee and direct the work of lower employees on a daily basis.
   “Workweek” means seven consecutive 24-hour periods, i.e., 168 consecutive
hours, designated by the employer.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.02 PROBATION.
145.02.1 PROBATIONARY PERIOD.
   Upon appointment by the Mayor and/or Council or other appropriate appointing
authority, all appointees shall serve a minimum probationary period of six (6)
months unless specified to the contrary in a current collective bargaining
agreement. At the end of that probation period, that employee may be eligible
for full-time status appointment. Until so appointed, prior to the end of the
probation period, the employee shall be considered a probationary appointee.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.02.2 FULL-TIME STATUS.
   At the completion of the probationary period, non-safety personnel may
attain full-time status, unless the department head or immediate supervisor,
upon approval of the Council, extends the probationary period. Such extension
must be made in accordance with applicable state and local law. No probationary
period may be extended beyond a maximum of one (1) year.
   The probationary period for safety personnel shall be for six months and in
accordance with state law. No extension may be granted. No final appointment of
safety personnel shall be made unless recommended by the Mayor and approved by
the Council.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.02.3 DISCIPLINARY ACTION.
   Probationers may be removed, demoted, or disciplined at any time during the
probationary period by written notice to the employee by the appointing
authority if and when the department head or immediate supervisor indicates
that his/her performance is unsatisfactory. Such removal or demotion shall not
be subject to appeal. Copies of all such notices involving removal or demotion
shall be filed with the Council.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.02.4 FALSE CREDENTIALS.
   If it should come to the attention of an employee's supervisor, either
during the probationary period, or thereafter, that an employee was hired on
the basis of false credentials, or other intentional deception said employee
will be subject to disciplinary procedures, up to and including dismissal.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.02.5 PROBATIONARY PERIOD FOLLOWING PROMOTION.
   Whenever an employee is promoted, he or she immediately begins a new
probationary period of the same length as would be served by an employee in an
original appointment to that classification. However, if during the
probationary period following promotion the employee's services are found
unsatisfactory, he or she may be reduced to the position, which he or she held
prior to promotion. If an employee is demoted during his or her probationary
period following promotion, this action will complete the probationary period.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.03 PAY SCHEDULE.
145.03.1 PAYMENT OF WAGES.
   Salaries and compensation will be determined by ordinance or resolution of
Council. Employees will be paid bi-weekly (26 pay periods annually). Payroll
will be prepared by the Village Clerk. The payroll check is based upon an
eighty (80) hour period, ten (10) eight (8) hour days, unless part-time,
seasonal or salaried. The pay period starts every other Sunday and runs for
(14) calendar days.
   The Clerk shall specify the format of a time sheet to ensure proper
documentation of hours worked by all employees. Time sheets must be signed by
the employee and his/her supervisor before submission to the Village Clerk.
   If an employee is absent on payday, he or she should notify either the Clerk
or a supervisor. He or she will determine the time and place for the employee
to receive his or her check. It will not be released to anyone else, unless
prior arrangements have been made.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.03.2 NEW EMPLOYEES.
   Generally, a new employee shall be paid the minimum rate of pay for his or
her class. The minimum rate for each class is based upon the assumption that a
new employee meets the minimum qualifications stated in the class/job
description. If a new employee more than meets the minimum qualifications for a
position, he or she may be appointed at the second step or in unusual cases at
a still higher step. Cases will be thoroughly analyzed and measured against
objective standards.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.03.3 PROMOTIONS.
   When an employee is promoted to a new position, that employee's salary shall
be increased to the minimum rate for the higher class. Except in the case of
overlapping ranges and when the employee to be promoted is at or above the
minimum step of the class to which promoted, the promoted employee shall, as a
minimum, be increased to the dollar step immediately above his or her present
salary.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.03.4 DEMOTIONS.
   When an employee is demoted, that employee shall be paid at a rate, which is
within the approved range for the lower classification. The rate of pay shall
be set by the Council taking into consideration the circumstances and
surrounding reasons for the demotion, and any other factors.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.03.5 TRANSFERS.
   After successful completion of the probationary period, any employee may be
transferred to the same or similar position within the department or in a
different department without being subject to a probationary period. An
employee desiring to be transferred should make the request in a letter to the
appointing authority. The heads of both divisions and departments involved must
approve a transfer.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.03.6 PAY APPROPRIATION.
   All salary increases are subject to availability of funds as determined by
the Village Clerk and the Council.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.03.7 TEMPORARY, PART-TIME, OR SEASONAL EMPLOYMENT.
   Compensation for provisional, temporary, part-time or seasonal employees is
established by the Council.
   Specifically, part-time position is established for fire and rescue to
include EMT, paramedics, and volunteers. Said position is limited to twenty-
nine (29) hours per week with no benefits. The rate of pay is to be set
annually by Council and the duties as required by the Mayor.
(Ord. O-22-043. Passed 12-12-22.)
145.03.8 OVERTIME.
   Overtime will be paid to appropriate employees classified as non-exempt
according to the federal Fair Labor Standards Act at a rate of one and one-half
times their calculated hourly rate for time worked beyond forty (40) hours per
standard work week.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.03.9 CALL IN PAY FOR HOURLY EMPLOYEES.
   Employees called in for emergency work will be paid a minimum of four hours
at their 1.5 rate of pay.
(Ord. O-18-001. Passed 2-5-18.)
145.03.10 GARNISHMENT/CHILD SUPPORT.
   A claim may be made against an employee's salary for unpaid debts. This
claim is called a garnishment and is a court order, which requires the Village
Clerk to make a deduction from the employee's paycheck to pay a debt. A claim
may also include court ordered child support payments.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.03.11 CASH ADVANCE POLICY.
   It is the policy of the Village that no advance in an employee's pay be
made, regardless of need. This policy is necessary for the protection of public
funds with which the Village is entrusted.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
 
145.03.12 LONGEVITY.
   (a)   All current and future full-time, hourly and salaried employees
(excluding all contract, seasonal, and part-time employees and elected
officials) of the Village shall receive longevity pay for continuous service
with the Village as follows:
Length of Service Amount Per Month
After 3 years     $ 33.00
After 4 years  44.00
After 5 years     55.00
After 6 years     66.00
After 7 years     77.00
After 8 years     88.00
After 9 years     99.00
After 10 years    111.00
After 11 years    121.00
After 12 years    132.00
After 13 years    143.00
After 14 years    154.00
After 15 years    165.00
After 16 years    176.00
After 17 years    187.00
After 18 years    198.00
After 19 years    209.00
After 20 years    220.00
   (b)   Longevity pay shall be calculated commencing three years from the
first day of employment (anniversary date) and shall be paid to eligible
employees.
(Ord. O-23-044. Passed 7-5-23.)
145.04 DISCIPLINE.
145.04.1 OFFENSES.
   Every employee in the service of the Village shall be expected to exhibit
good behavior, and perform efficient and effective service. Any employee of the
Village may be disciplined for any of the following offenses:
   Note: this list is provided only as an example and is not exhaustive.
   (a)    Conviction of any criminal offense.
   (b)    Fighting, threatening or attempting bodily injury to another;
stealing, malicious mischief resulting in the injury or destruction of property
of other employees or the Village of North Kingsville.
   (c)    Consumption of alcohol while on the job or during work hours.
   (d)    Use, or possession, of habit-forming drugs or hallucinogens.
   (e)    Unethical conduct on Village time.
   (f)    Insubordination, including but not limited to, refusal or failure to
perform work assignments and the use of profane or abusive language to
supervisors, employees or officers of the Village, and absence from duty
without notice or permission of the supervisor.
   (g)    Willful neglect in the care or use of Village property and equipment.
   (h)    Failure to satisfactorily perform the duties for which employed.
   (i)    Gross or habitual carelessness or recklessness, playing of tricks,
jokes or other dangerous pranks upon others. Disregard for safety and comfort
of fellow employees.
   (j)    Engaging in outside employment without written notification to and
written approval of the Mayor.
   (k)    Repeated failure to report to work on time and ready for work.
   (l)    Incurring costs or obligations in the name of the Village without the
authority or prior approval.
   (m)    Discourteous and/or unprofessional treatment of the public.
   (n)    Failure to comply with the provisions of this document.
   (o)    Any violation of Village Work Rules, Regulations or Standard
Operation Procedures documents.
      (Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.04.2 TYPES OF DISCIPLINE.
   Disciplinary action shall consist of one or more of the following:
   (a)    Verbal warning.
   (b)    Written warnings.
   (c)    Suspension from duty without pay.
   (d)    Demotion in rank and/or salary.
   (e)    Dismissal.
      (Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.04.3 DISCIPLINARY PROCEDURE.
   The Department Heads concerned shall be responsible for the discipline of
employees within their departments. Discipline may be progressive in nature and
shall be applied based upon a combination of factors, including the severity of
the offense, past history of the employee and past disciplinary actions against
the employee.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.04.3.1 DEPARTMENT HEAD DISCIPLINARY AUTHORITY AND RESPONSIBILITY.
   Department Heads may issue verbal warnings and written warnings to members
of their departments and should provide any documentation to the Mayor.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.04.3.2 MAYOR DISCIPLINARY AUTHORITY.
   The Mayor may enforce any of the types of discipline, including termination,
where appropriate and in accordance with any applicable statutes or local laws.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.04.3.3 EMPLOYEE NOTIFICATION.
   (a)   For disciplinary measures that are more severe than a verbal warning,
the disciplined employee will be informed in writing of the right to appeal the
disciplinary action to the Council.
 
   (b)   The written order will be provided to the employee prior to the
effective time of the order for all disciplinary actions.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.04.4 APPEAL PROCEDURES.
   Disciplinary actions need not be deferred pending the possible submission of
an appeal.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.04.4.1 EMPLOYEE'S RESPONSIBILITY.
   Any employee feeling aggrieved by either a suspension of more than three (3)
days or a change of status (e.g., dismissal or demotion) may, in writing,
appeal the disciplinary action to the Council.
   (a)    The appeal must be filed in writing with the Village Clerk and
Council within ten (10) days of the employee's receipt date of the written
notification of the disciplinary action from the Council. If the ten (10) day
appeal filing time is exceeded, the Council will take no action in the matter.
This appeal:
      (1)    Must be signed by the individual who is appealing and include both
his or her department and grade therein; and
      (2)    Must have attached thereto a copy of the disciplinary order.
   (b)    The employee will present the written request for an appeal hearing
in dispassionate language and shall not vilify the character or motivation of
the Department Head or Council. The written request should specify either or
both of the following grounds for appeal:
      (1)    There was a failure on the part of a Village official to observe
or correctly apply the provisions of the Personnel Rules or the terms of the
subject's appointment; and/or
      (2)    There was not a complete consideration of the facts regarding the
disciplinary action taken against the appellant.
   (c)    The appeal hearing request should contain all written material truly
relevant to the case.
    (d)    The Council will be provided a copy of all material presented in the
request for an appeal hearing when it is filed.
   (e)   Hearings will normally be closed to the public. However, the appellant
may request that it be open at the time he or she submits the written appeal.
      (Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.04.4.2 COUNCIL RESPONSIBILITY AND AUTHORITY.
   (a)    The Council shall set a time for an appeal hearing promptly and
should strive to have the hearing date no later than ten days after receiving
the request for an appeals hearing.
 
   (b)    The Council will review all written material submitted to it. If
present, the Council shall hear the appellant or his or her counsel. If
present, the Council shall hear the Department Head or counsel. The Council
will examine evidence upon the matter that may be pertinent and relevant.
 
   (c)    The Council may affirm, disaffirm or modify the disciplinary measure
taken against the employee.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.04.4.3 POLICE OFFICERS: DISCIPLINE, TERMINATION, AND RIGHT OF APPEAL.
   Sections 737.171 and 737.19 of the Revised Code govern the discipline and
termination of the Police Chief and police officers. As provided by Ohio R.C.
737.171 and 737.19, a certified police officer may appeal a decision of the
Council for removal to the Court of Common Pleas.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.04.5 TERMINATION.
   At the time an employee is terminated, for whatever reason, the following
steps must be taken prior to receipt of final pay:
   (a)    Provide the Village Clerk with the proper forwarding address in order
to receive W-2 forms and any other pertinent information needed to file the
current year's income tax returns.
   (b)    Turn in uniforms, tools, building keys, keys to Village offices and/
or any other Village property to his or her immediate supervisor. A receipt
will be issued to the employee for all property returned.
   (c)    Advise the Village Clerk as to the type of action desired with regard
to employee's retirement plan.
      (Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.05 LAYOFF/RECALL.
145.05.1 WORK FORCE REDUCTION (Does not apply to seasonal employees).
   Should a reduction in the work force of the Village of North Kingsville be
necessary, that reduction shall occur in the manner prescribed as follows: The
Council shall determine those employees, which shall be reduced in number. Such
reduction will take place solely in those employees as determined by the
Council. Employees may be laid off at the time and in the number specified by
the Council, in inverse order of their relative merit as established by
employee performance evaluations. All part-time employees may be laid off
before the probationary employees and all probationary employees before full-
time employees.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
 
145.05.2 RECALL ELIGIBILITY LIST (Does not apply to seasonal employees).
   The names of individuals laid off in accordance with this section shall be
placed on a recall eligibility list for a period of 12 months at which time the
list be declared invalid. The order of that list shall be in inverse order of
the order in which the layoff occurred.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
 
145.05.3 RECALL TO WORK (Does not apply to seasonal employees).
   When situations so warrant, those employees who have been laid off shall be
called back to work in the order as indicated on the recall eligibility list.
Should an employee be unavailable to return to work in a period of time as
deemed reasonable by the Council, or refuse to return to work, that employee's
name shall be removed from the re-employment list. Any such employee shall be
eligible to apply for original appointment in accordance with the appropriate
section of these Personnel Rules and Regulations.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
 
145.06 HOURS OF WORK AND COMPUTATION OF PAY.
145.06.1 STANDARD WORK WEEK.
   The standard workweek for employees shall be forty (40) hours per week,
eight (8) hours per day, five (5) days per week. Village Offices shall be open
to the public from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., Monday through Thursday, and 8:00
a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Fridays, and closed on Saturday, Sunday, and legal holidays.
The Council may vary these hours according to need or improve the efficient
delivery of services. (Ord. O-20-053. Passed 11-18-20.)
145.06.2 COMPUTATION OF PAY.
   An hourly employee's pay shall be computed by multiplying the hourly rate by
the hours in the standard workweek. A salaried employee's pay shall be computed
on the basis of a twenty- six week pay period for each year. Pay will be
disbursed to employees at intervals not to exceed every two weeks on days
determined by the Council.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.06.3 AUTHORIZED LEAVE.
   Employees are required to be at work during the prescribed hours unless on
authorized leave as determined below. Should employees be unable to report for
work, it will be incumbent upon the employee to report that inability prior to
commencement of the regular work shift. Employees shall notify the Village
immediately as to when they will return to work.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07 PAID TIME OFF.
145.07.1 GENERAL POLICIES.
145.07.1.1 COMBINING PAID TIME OFF/LEAVES.
   Employees who are currently on authorized leave may extend the leave by
combining two forms of leave. In any instance, after a type of leave has
expired, vacation time will be used for any remaining days away from work.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.1.2 UNSCHEDULED ABSENCE FROM WORK.
   Employees who are going to be absent from work on a non-scheduled basis
shall notify their immediate supervisor at least two (2) hours prior to the
start of the normally scheduled work period. Employees shall not absent
themselves from duty without the permission of the Department Head. Department
Heads shall not absent themselves from duty without the permission of the
Mayor.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.1.3 SPECIAL PERIODS.
   The Mayor may deny leave requests of any kind during special periods such as
an emergency situation or departmental need.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.2 HOLIDAY LEAVE.
   The following days shall be observed as holidays by full-time employees of
the Village of North Kingsville:
   New Year's Day,
   Martin Luther King Day,
   Presidents Day,
   Memorial Day,
   June 19th Juneteenth
   Independence Day,
   Labor Day,
   Columbus Day,
   Veterans Day,
   Thanksgiving Day, and
   Christmas Day.
   The dates for observation shall be those designated at the Federal level,
unless otherwise provided by the Village Council.
   When a holiday falls on a Saturday, the preceding Friday is observed. When a
holiday falls on a Sunday, the following Monday is observed. Village offices
are closed on legal holidays as appointed by the Council or Governor, only when
ratified by the Village of North Kingsville Council.
   To be eligible for a paid holiday, the employee must work his/her regularly
scheduled shift the day before and the day after the holiday or present just
cause to his or her supervisor justifying the absence.
(Ord. O-21-064. Passed 1-19-22.)
145.07.2.1 WORKING ON A HOLIDAY.
   When an employee is required, by schedule, to work on any of the above
holidays, he or she shall receive total pay of two and one half times regular
rate of pay.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.2.2 HOLIDAY DURING LEAVE.
   Employees will not be paid for holidays, which occur during a leave of
absence or disciplinary action. If a holiday occurs during a period of sick
leave, the employee will be regarded as having taken the holiday and will not
be charged for sick leave. A holiday occurring while an employee is on vacation
will be counted as a holiday and not as a vacation day.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.2.3 RELIGIOUS HOLIDAY.
   Special holidays of a religious nature may be allowed without pay upon
advance request of the individual employee. Requests submitted to the
department head and/or Council at least one month in advance will, as much as
possible, be authorized. Reasonable effort shall be made by the department head
or Council to accommodate all requests submitted after that period.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.3 VACATION LEAVE.
   (a)   In order to use vacation time, an employee must have completed one
year of service with the Village. Employees must be in an active pay status to
accrue vacation leave.
 
   (b)   The vacation accrual schedule is as follows:
      (1)   One year of service and up to five years of service        80 hours
      (2)   Five years of service and up to ten years of service    120 hours
      (3)   Ten years of service and up to twenty years of service    160 hours
      (4)   Twenty or more years of service             200 hours
   (c)   Employees will be granted vacation leave credit in accordance with
Ohio R.C. 9.44.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
   (d)   Vacation Buy Back Policy.
      (1)   All vacation time must be used in the year it is earned or be lost
by the employee without compensation.
      (2)   If an employee considers that they have extraordinary and special
circumstances as to why they cannot use their vacation time, said employee may
make a request for up to one (1) week vacation buy back.
      (3)   Requests, for up to one (1) week vacation buy back shall be made to
the employee’s supervisor. The supervisor shall notify the Mayor and the Mayor
shall timely grant or deny said request and thereafter notify the supervisor
and the Chairperson of the Finance Committee.
         (Ord. O-20-026. Passed 6-1-20.)
145.07.4 MILITARY LEAVE.
   The Village shall not refuse to employ nor shall it discharge any person
because of membership with the Ohio National Guard, the Ohio Defense Corps, the
Ohio Naval Militia, the Armed Services of the United States or their
auxiliaries or prevent him or her from performing any military service as he or
she may be called upon to perform, by proper authority.
   An employee of the Village shall be granted a leave of absence to be
inducted or otherwise enter military duty. If not accepted for such duty, he or
she shall be reinstated in his or her position without loss of seniority or
reduction in his or her pay rate.
   When such military service (including National Guard and reserve duty) is
carried out at the option of the employee, the Village will grant the employee
a military leave of absence without pay. (Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.5 CIVIL LEAVE.
   An employee shall be given necessary time off without loss of pay when
performing jury duty, appearing in court as a witness in answer to a subpoena,
in an official capacity in connection with the Village or as an expert witness
either because of professional or observed knowledge, performing emergency
civilian duty in connection with national defense, and for the purposes of
voting when the polls open at least two hours before or after the employee's
scheduled hours of work. An employee must notify his or her supervisor five
days prior to jury duty or service date. Any compensation received while on
civil leave will be deducted from the employee's pay. If jury pay is higher
than that paid by the Village, the employee is permitted to keep the
difference. If the employee is on vacation or personal leave, he or she is
allowed to keep the pay.
   If an employee is involved in court in a personal case either as plaintiff
or as defendant in a suit not resulting from his duties with the Village, he or
she may be granted leave without pay unless the employee elects to utilize any
available vacation time.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.6 INJURY LEAVE.
   Injury leave is time away from work because the employee is disabled due to
an injury whether caused by external accidental means or accidental in
character received in the course of or arising out of the injured employee's
employment with the Village. The determination of eligibility for commencement
and termination of injury leave status shall be made by the appointing
authority subject to review by the Council upon written request by the employee
within 10 days of any such determination. The employee shall be required as a
condition of eligibility for injury leave status to furnish the Council
information as required by them necessary to make a determination.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.7 FUNERAL AND BEREAVEMENT LEAVE.
   Regular employees are permitted to use up to three days of bereavement leave
whenever there is a death in the immediate family (spouse and children) or
whenever one of the following dies: father, mother step-parent brother, sister,
mother-in-law, father-in-law, brother-in law, sister-in-law, grandparent,
grandchild or other person designated by the Council.
   Leave of absence without pay is allowed for other funerals when approved by
the employee's supervisor.
   Employee's seeking to use sick leave or funeral leave are required to call
their supervisor at least 2 hours prior to their regular starting time. Failure
to do so will result in the employee being counted as missing, thus no sick
leave benefit will be paid and the employee is subject to further disciplinary
action. Persons working shift work should give at least two hours notice so
that a replacement can be found.
   In order for leave to be paid, the employee may be required to provide
documentation to the Mayor. This information may consist of either a letter
from the funeral home or a newspaper obituary.
145.07.8 SICK LEAVE.
   Sick leave is time for which a full-time employee is compensated at his or
her regular rate when absent due to illness or another medically related
reason, such as a doctor's appointment. Example: An employee earns sick leave
time at the rate of ten (10) hours per month of service. Example: Sick leave
can be accumulated up to a maximum of 160 days for conversion upon retirement.
Upon retirement twenty-five percent of accumulated sick leave time shall be
paid to all full-time Village employees. There is no maximum for accumulation
for use. The smallest increment of sick leave, which may be used, is one hour.
   Nothing in this section shall be construed as to require the Mayor to
approve the use of sick leave by an employee when the Mayor is reasonably
certain that the employee was not ill or was not absent for the other reasons
permitted by this section. Examples of when the Mayor may not approve sick
leave are: concerted use of sick leave by an employee singly or in concert with
others as a means of withholding services; a chronic abuse of sick leave in an
established pattern; or other situations where past history and facts do not
substantiate the legitimate use of sick leave. The appointing authority may
investigate all usage of sick leave and may withhold full payment of said sick
leave until the investigation is completed.
   Should the Mayor determine that an employee has not used sick leave
properly, payment may be denied and discipline imposed. Employees who do not
report for work due to sickness, and who have exhausted their sick leave days,
are subject to disciplinary action for being absent without approved leave. The
Mayor is authorized to approve leave without pay to employees in this situation
where it is determined that such action is in the best interest of the Village.
   New employees are eligible for sick leave after successful completion of the
probationary period of six months of employment. Seasonal employees earn no
sick leave benefits. Sick leave does not accumulate while an employee is on
suspension or any unpaid leave of absence in excess of one month. (Ord. O-03-
018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.8.1 REASONS.
   Sick leave may be used for absence due to temporary disability caused by
illness, injury, pregnancy or for exposure to contagious or communicable
disease which may be transmitted to fellow employees. Any such absence shall
begin when the temporary disability or exposure shall be so severe as to
prohibit an employee from attendance at work and shall cease when an employee
is able to return to work. Sick leave may also be used for a family emergency
resulting from illness or injury to an employee's spouse, children or other
dependents residing in the employee's household. The emergency must require the
employee's presence at home or at the health care provider.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.8.2 DOCUMENTATION.
   An employee absent on sick leave for more than three (3) days shall submit a
claim for sick leave. For a sick leave absence of three days or less, Mayor may
require employees to furnish a claim for sick leave form. Failure to submit the
sick leave claim form when required will result in the employee being
determined to be on leave without pay and a deduction in the subsequent payroll
period. The claim form should be forwarded with the employee's time sheet.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.8.3 NOTICE.
   Employees seeking to use sick leave should call a supervisor two hours prior
to their regular starting time. Failure to do so may result in the employee
being counted as missing - no sick leave benefit will be paid and the employee
will be subject to disciplinary action. Employees on shift work should give at
least two hours notice so that a replacement can be found.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.8.4 CASHING OF SICK LEAVE.
   An employee who retires and meets the age and length of service requirements
of the Public Employees Retirement System (PERS) or the Police and Fire Pension
Fund (PFPF), whichever is applicable, may redeem twenty-five percent of 160
days.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.8.5 TRANSFER OF SICK LEAVE.
   Any employee may file a written request with the fiscal officer of the
Village to have a portion of their accumulated sick leave transferred to
another Village employee that has eliminated or is about to eliminate all of
their personal sick leave. No transferred sick leave may be accumulated by the
receiving employee toward retirement benefits.
(Ord. 13-037. Passed 6-21-13.)
145.07.9 MATERNITY LEAVE.
   Maternity leave will be considered under the Family and Medical Leave Act.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.10 LEAVES OF ABSENCE.
   A leave of absence may be approved by the Mayor under the following
conditions:
   (a)    Leave of absence is always without pay.
   (b)    Leave of absence may only be granted to regular, full-time employees
who have successfully completed their probationary period.
   (c)    The request for a leave of absence must be in writing from the
employee outlining the reasons for the leave.
   (d)    On any approved leave of absence in excess of one month, the employee
shall pay the total premium cost for his medical and life insurance for the
duration of the leave. This cost is to be paid in advance of the first month of
the leave and prior to each month thereafter or the coverage will be
terminated.
   (e)    Failure to return from a leave of absence at the specified date will
be considered as a resignation.
   (f)    All approved leaves of absence shall be confirmed in writing to the
employee by the Mayor with a copy to the employee's file.
   (g)    Vacation and sick leave do not accrue on a leave of absence in excess
of one month. Vacation allowance is paid at the time of departure on the amount
unused and accrued. Any sick days accumulated prior to the leave may be
reinstated immediately upon return.
   (h)    Re-employment, if applicable, should be part, or the condition of,
the leave of absence. If not, the employee is subject to the availability of
employment at the time of his or her requested return. Employees returning from
military service are subject to the Veterans Re-employment Rights Act.
   (i)    There are several types of leaves of absence. They include:
      (1)    Medical: Time away from the job because of accident or illness not
covered by sick leave.
       (2)    Self Improvement: Schooling.
      (3)    Personal: Time needed to handle personal problems.
         (Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.11 UNAUTHORIZED LEAVE.
   Any absence from work which is not detailed in this section of these
Personnel Rules and Regulations shall be considered an unauthorized absence
from duty. Any such unauthorized absence from duty shall constitute just cause
for disciplinary action.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.07.12 FAMILY AND MEDICAL LEAVE.
   The Village will provide eligible employees a leave of absence for specific
reasons and subject to guidelines as defined by the Family and Medical Leave
Act (FMLA). Eligible employees shall be provided up to twelve (12) weeks of
leave during any twelve-month period in connection with specific qualifying
events. Employees must be restored to the position occupied when the leave
began or to an "equivalent position" with equivalent conditions of employment.
145.08 COMPENSATORY TIME.
145.08.1 ESTABLISHED.
   Employees of the Village of North Kingsville may be entitled to compensatory
time (accrued at 1 and ½ hours for each hour of overtime), instead of paid
overtime. The Mayor may, from time to time, establish the use of compensatory
time for individual departments if the situation necessitates such a policy.
(Ord. 0-17-011. Passed 4-3-17.)
145.08.2 USE OF COMPENSATORY TIME.
   Accumulated compensatory time must be earned and used within the same year
unless permission is given by the Mayor to use it at a later period.
(Ord. 0-17-011. Passed 4-3-17.)
145.08.3 MAXIMUM ACCRUEMENT.
   Employees generally may accrue up to eighty (80) hours of compensatory time.
(Ord. O-17-011. Passed 4-3-17.)
145.08.4 COMPENSATION TIME FOR SALARIED EMPLOYEES.
   Salaried employees are not subject to Sections
145.08.1 through
145.08.3.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.09 BENEFITS: PERS AND INSURANCE.
145.09.1 PERS AND PFDPF CONTRIBUTION.
   Generally, all employees, except fire and police personnel, are required to
be a member of the State of Ohio Public Employee Retirement System. The Village
will deduct 8.5 percent of the employee's gross wages or salary as the
employee's contribution to PERS. The Village is required to make a contribution
on behalf of the employee each quarter. The Village contribution may vary -
- the current amount is 13.55 percent of the employee's gross wages or salary.
Generally, full-time police and fire personnel participate in the State of Ohio
Police and Fire Pension Fund. Employee contributions are deducted from their
gross earnings before taxes are applied. Part-time police officers participate
in PERS. Part-time fire personnel, hired after August 3, 1992, participate in
Social Security (FICA) instead of PERS.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.09.2 WORKER'S COMPENSATION.
   All Village employees are protected at Village expense under Ohio Worker's
Compensation Program. From this fund, medical expenses are covered for workers
who suffer injury or certain kinds of illness in the course of their
employment. In addition, if workers are temporarily unable to work as a result
of such injury or illness, weekly disability payments are made to them after
they complete an initial waiting period.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.09.2.1 NOTIFICATION OF INJURY.
   When an employee is injured, he or she must notify the immediate supervisor,
or the Mayor, at once. In each case of injury on the job, it is the
responsibility of the supervisor or the Mayor to establish the validity of the
claim. This includes a determination that the injury was actually sustained in
the performance of the employee's duties. Should a supervisor find that the
injury did not occur on the job, the facts of the case should be reported to
the Mayor in writing. When an employee is injured on the job, a written
explanation or "injury investigation report" should be prepared by the employee
and his or her immediate supervisor. All required information must be supplied
and submitted within five (5) days following the injury. All injuries should be
reported at once. Failure to report an injury may preclude approval by the
Bureau of Workers' Compensation and can result in disciplinary action against
the employee for failure to comply.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.09.3 INSURANCE.
   All regular full-time employees are covered by the group medical insurance
program provided for employees of the Village, unless the employee opts not to
accept the coverage because of coverage under another policy. On or before
March 31 each year the employee must notify the clerk in writing of the
decision to opt out. A single employee that opts out of this insurance coverage
shall receive four hundred dollars ($400.00) per month of no insurance coverage
as additional wages. An employee under the family plan that opts out of this
insurance coverage shall receive eight hundred dollars ($800.00) per month of
no insurance coverage as additional wages. This includes:
   (a)    Group medical insurance for employee and dependents: Hospitalization
and Major Medical with Full Miscellaneous.
   For a complete description of insurance benefits, please contact the
appropriate insurance provider.
(Ord. O-23-035. Passed 6-21-23.)
145.09.4 TRAVEL EXPENSES.
   Travel expenses must be authorized in advance by the appropriate Council
committee. Full- time, regular employees will be reimbursed for necessary
expenses incurred while attending schools of instruction, institutes, or
conventions of a nature relating to the art and science of their particular
employment. Full-time regular employees will be reimbursed for expenses when
using their private automobile while discharging duties connected with their
employment. If Village employees use their private automobile in the conduct of
official business, shall be compensated at the rate determined by the Council.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.10 EMPLOYEE EVALUATION SYSTEM.
   An Employee Evaluation/Appraisal Plan may be adopted as part of a
Comprehensive Personnel System. One possible plan includes the follows
provisions:
145.10.1 EVALUATIONS.
   Each employee will be evaluated upon completion of the probationary period
and, from that point further, at least once every year. Such evaluation will be
in writing and carried out by the employee's supervisor and placed permanently
in his or her personnel file. All such evaluations shall be shown to the
employee being rated and discussed thoroughly with him or her.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.10.2 PERSONNEL STATUS CHANGE FORMS.
   The Council shall prescribe the necessary forms to report all personnel
changes in the Village service, which shall be used by all appointing officers
and supervisors.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.11 EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT.
145.11.1 RETIREMENT.
   Any employee of the Village of North Kingsville who is eligible to retire
under the applicable rules, regulations, and statutes of the State of Ohio
shall be permitted to do so in accordance with the rules of the Public
Employees Retirement System or the Police and Fire Pension Fund. All employees
if possible should notify the Council at least six (6) months prior to
retirement.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.11.1.2 CASHING OF SICK LEAVE.
   An employee who retires and meets the age and length of service requirements
of the Public Employees Retirement System (PERS) or the Police and Fire Pension
Fund, whichever is applicable, may redeem accumulated sick leave. Example: Such
redemption shall be at a rate of four (4) accumulated sick leave hours
exchanged for one (1) hour of pay at the employee's last rate of regular pay
prior to such retirement, up to a maximum conversion of one fourth of 160 days.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.11.2 DISABILITY RETIREMENT.
   Any employee of the Village of North Kingsville who desires to apply for
disability retirement through the Public Employees Retirement System or the
Police and Fire Pension Fund may be required to submit to an examination by a
physician.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.12 EMPLOYEE RESIGNATION.
145.12.1 PROPER NOTICE.
   Employees who resign their employment should give a minimum of two weeks
notice in writing prior to the effective date of the resignation.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.12.2 SICK LEAVE.
   An employee may be eligible to carry forward accumulated sick leave from the
Village of North Kingsville to another public employer in Ohio. Generally, the
cashing out of sick leave is only available in cases of retirement from public
service.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.12.3 PROCEDURE.
   At the time an employee resigns, for whatever reason, the following steps
must be taken prior to receipt of final pay:
    (a)    Notify the Village Clerk to ensure that the proper forwarding
address is recorded in order to receive W-2 forms and any other pertinent
information needed to file the current year's income tax returns. Also, provide
the Village Clerk as to the type of action desired with regard to employee's
retirement plan.
   (b)    Turn in uniforms, tools, building keys, keys to Village plants or
offices and/or any other Village property to his or her immediate supervisor.
      (Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.13 PERSONNEL FILES AND RECORDS.
145.13.1 PERTINENT INFORMATION.
   The appointing authority shall create, or cause to be created, a personnel
file for each employee of the Village. Such a file shall include the original
application and the notice of appointment in addition to other information that
may be pertinent. The file will be maintained by the Village Clerk and shall be
the official personnel file.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.13.2 ACCESSING FILES.
   Access to the personnel files shall be in accordance to the Ohio law
regarding public records.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.13.3 UPDATING FILE.
   It is the responsibility of the employee to initiate any needed changes. An
employee's education, training and experience background information are
important factors in the promotion procedure. These items should be reviewed by
the employee periodically to be sure they are up-to- date. Also, the employee
should notify the Village Clerk of any changes in marital status or dependents
as they may relate to insurance coverage.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.14 SPECIFIC RULES AND REGULATIONS.
145.14.1 ATTENDANCE POLICY.
   The Village of North Kingsville defines an absence as failure to report for
and remain at work as scheduled; this includes late arrival at work and leaving
early. Absence then includes all time lost from the job whether excused or
unexcused, avoidable or unavoidable. The only exceptions to this definition of
absence are holidays, vacations, death in the immediate family, Worker's
Compensation cases, approved leaves of absence, and days for which no work is
scheduled.
(Ord. O-03-018. Passed 5-21-03.)
145.14.2 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
145.14.2.1 OHIO ETHICS LAW.
   The Ohio Ethics Law applies to all Village officers and employees. The
Village will provide a copy of the Ohio Ethics Law to all officers and
employees within 15 days after they begin service to the Village. No Village
officer or employee may take any action to purchase or acquire services or
property for the Village where they, their family, or their business associates
have a financial interest in the service or property. No Village officer or
employee may take any action to employ his or her spouse, parents,
grandparents, children, grandchildren, brothers, or sisters and any relatives
