951.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Commercial or commercially" means relating to or connected with a
trade or business.
   (b)    "Garbage" means all refuse accumulations of any fruit or vegetable
matter that attend the preparation, use or storage of meat, fish, fruits or
vegetables, or any work or other activity involving such items, or containers
originally used for foodstuffs.
   (c)    "Hauler" means a person who receives compensation for transporting
over Village streets or dumping or discarding solid wastes, or any person
owning vehicles or employing drivers for such purposes.
   (d)    "Refuse" means garbage, rubbish or both.
   (e)    "Resident" means any occupant, tenant, landlord, family, individual
or group of individuals occupying or maintaining a dwelling for the purpose of
creating a home, shelter or domicile in the Village.
   (f)    "Rubbish" means all refuse other than garbage, rocks, concrete blocks
and similar solid material, plaster or dirt.
   (g)   "Solid waste" means unwanted residual solid or semisolid material that
results from industrial, commercial, agricultural, residential and community
operations, excluding earth or material from construction, mining or demolition
operations and slag and other substances which are not harmful or inimical to
public health. The term includes garbage, combustible and noncombustible
material, putrescible and nonputrescible wastes, street dirt and debris.
      (Ord. 73-5.1. Passed 9-2-75.)
951.02  LICENSE REQUIRED; CONDITIONS FOR ISSUANCE.
   (a)    No person shall engage in hauling refuse, garbage, rubbish or solid
waste in the Village, or park a motor vehicle used in hauling refuse, garbage,
rubbish or solid waste in the Village, without first obtaining a license
therefor from the Clerk-Treasurer or the Mayor.
(Ord. 73-5.1. Passed 9-2-75.)
   (b)   A license shall be issued by the Clerk-Treasurer or Mayor when the
Clerk- Treasurer or Mayor has determine(d) that:
      (1)   The applicant has been satisfactorily completed;
      (2)   Evidence of current public liability insurance in a sum of not less
than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000) is provided to the Clerk-
Treasurer;
      (3)   A copy of the rules and regulations have been received by the
applicant;
      (4)   The license fee has been paid.
         (Ord. O-06-089. Passed 1-17-07.)
951.03  LICENSE APPLICATIONS; INSURANCE; BOND; TERM OF LICENSES.
   Applicants for a license to haul refuse, garbage, rubbish or solid waste
shall complete and file with the Clerk-Treasurer or the Mayor an application on
a form prescribed by the Clerk- Treasurer or the Mayor and shall give such
information as may be required. All applicants shall furnish evidence of
existing public liability insurance in a sum of not less than two hundred
thousand dollars ($200,000). All applicants shall give bond in the sum of three
thousand dollars ($3,000) from a reputable surety as a guarantee of compliance
with this chapter. Applications for licenses shall be filed by October 1 of
each year, and all licenses issued shall be for a period of one year only.
(Ord. 73-5.1. Passed 9-2-75.)
951.04  LICENSE FEES.
   The fee for the license required in this chapter shall be one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per year, or part thereof, for each motor vehicle used by a
hauler to transport refuse, garbage, rubbish or solid waste on the public
streets of the Village, and fifty dollars ($50.00) per year, or part thereof,
for each motor vehicle parked in the Village and used in hauling refuse,
garbage, rubbish or solid waste.
(Ord. 73-5.1. Passed 9-2-75.)
951.05  RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR HAULERS.
   (a)    The issuance of a license to haul refuse, garbage, rubbish or solid
waste in the Village, or to park a motor vehicle used in hauling refuse,
garbage, rubbish or solid waste in the Village, shall be contingent upon
compliance with the rules and regulations set forth in this section.
   (b)    Any motor vehicle used for hauling refuse, garbage, rubbish or solid
waste in the Village shall satisfy all requirements of the Traffic Code and of
the Bureau of Motor Vehicles of the State. Any license obtained by an applicant
shall be permanently displayed in his or her place of business and the sticker
obtained shall be permanently displayed upon every vehicle hauling refuse,
garbage, rubbish or solid waste which is used or parked in the Village.
   (c)    Every motor vehicle used by a licensed hauler to transfer refuse,
garbage, rubbish or solid waste in the Village shall have an enclosed, leak-
proof body with permanent covers composed of metal, wood or fiberglass and
shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the Mayor or his or her
designee.
   (d)    Any motor vehicle used by a licensed hauler to transport refuse,
garbage, rubbish or solid waste shall not be parked in any residentially zoned
district or upon any public street in the Village between one-half hour after
sunset and one-half hour after sunrise. No hauler or other person shall park or
permit to be parked overnight a motor vehicle or trailer partially or fully
loaded with refuse, garbage, rubbish or solid waste in the Village if the
parking of such vehicle creates a nuisance. It shall be a prima-facie nuisance
if the following conditions exist at the parking site:
      (1)    Excessively offensive odors affecting neighboring properties;
      (2)    An excessive number of flies creating an unsanitary condition; and
      (3)    General unsanitary conditions which are attracting or are likely
to attract rats, rodents or similar animals. Any hauler or other person parking
or being permitted to park, overnight, a motor vehicle or trailer fully or
partially loaded with refuse, garbage, rubbish or solid waste in the Village,
shall secure the express written approval of the parking site by the Mayor or
his or her designee.
   (e)    Every motor vehicle which is used to haul refuse, garbage, rubbish or
solid waste and which is parked in the Village shall be cleaned daily with a
solution or solvent which is acceptable to the Mayor or his or her designee.
Each motor vehicle so used shall be subject to inspection by the Mayor or his
or her designee at a time which is convenient to both the hauler and the Mayor
or his or her designee. Inspections shall be made not less than three times per
week, except between May 1 and October 1, when inspections shall be made not
less than five times per week. Haulers shall comply with all reasonable orders
of the Clerk-Treasurer or the Mayor within a reasonable time.
   (f)    Any hauler desiring to increase his or her rate of transporting
refuse, garbage, rubbish or solid waste in the Village shall file such increase
with the Clerk-Treasurer or the Mayor setting forth the reasons therefor and
the effective date thereof.
(Ord. 73-5.1. Passed 9-2-75.)
951.06  PLACEMENT OF REFUSE FOR COLLECTION.
   (a)    A resident shall not place any refuse, garbage, rubbish or solid
waste outside his or her home or domicile unless such refuse, garbage, rubbish
or solid waste is placed in a garbage bag, trash bag, trash can or garbage
container. Garbage cans or garbage containers shall be of galvanized iron,
plastic or nonrusting material of substantial durability with tightly fitting
lids and of such size as can be easily handled by one person. A resident shall
not place any garbage bag, trash bag, garbage can or garbage container adjacent
to the curb for collection except upon the day designated for collection in the
district in which he or she resides, and not earlier than the day of collection
within the designated district.
   (b)    A resident shall not place or deposit adjacent to the curb for
collection any garbage, refuse, rubbish or solid waste without applying for and
obtaining service from a licensed hauler as described in this chapter.
(Ord. 73-5.1. Passed 9-2-75.)
951.99 PENALTY.
   (a)    Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of
this chapter, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree.
   (b)    Whoever violates or fails to comply with Section
951.06 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. (Ord. 73-5.1. Passed 9-2-75.)

the Village Green Golf Course on an ongoing basis of at least once per year and

without jeopardizing their safety or the safety of the public.
(Res. R-02-032. Passed 6-3-02.)

property is more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), such person is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree.

161
Burial permits - see Ohio R.C. 3706.24 et seq.
Burial of indigent persons - see Ohio R.C. 5101.521
 
 
963.01 GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   (a)    Council will use reasonable care in engaging competent and
experienced cemetery employees and in seeing that they do their work with
customary carefulness, but it hereby disclaims any responsibility or liability
for accident or damage to headstones, vases and monuments resulting from
ordinary hazards of cemetery work, nor does it assume any liability for
accident to persons or property due to defects of machinery, implements, tools
and equipment used in cemetery work.
   (b)    Grave surfaces shall be kept level with the surrounding terrain.
   (c)    Subject to the approval of the Board of Cemetery Trustees, the
planting of shrubs and flowers will be permitted on cemetery lots. Any planting
made in violation of this rule may be removed without notice. It is advisable
to make the necessary arrangements at the cemetery before planting material is
purchased.
   (d)    The Board may direct that any work done within cemetery grounds for
remuneration be performed by cemetery employees, under its supervision.
   (e)    If any tree or shrub standing on any lot, by means of its roots,
branches or otherwise, becomes detrimental, dangerous or inconvenient to
adjacent lots or walks, or if it becomes unsightly, the Board shall remove such
tree or shrub, or any portion thereof, as it judges best.
   (f)    No person shall remove turf for a flower bed or other purpose without
first obtaining the Board's permission.
   (g)    The cemetery will maintain, as nearly as may be practical, the
planting of trees and shrubs that are contained in the landscaping and general
background of the cemetery, but does not undertake to maintain plantings or
original growth of trees and shrubs on individual lots.
   (h)    No fence, hedge, enclosure or curbing of any kind will be allowed on
burial lots.
   (i)    Glassware, cans, crockery, boxes, baskets, shells or watering pots
left on graves or lots are detrimental to the appearance of the cemetery and
the Board shall remove such articles from the graves and lots. (Ord. 1024.
Passed 6-22-72.)
   (j)    No person shall deposit debris, rubbish or any other waste material
of any kind anywhere within cemetery limits. (Ord. 13-012. Passed 4-17-13.) 
   (k)    An order for special work in anticipation of Memorial Day must reach
the Board not later than May 1.
   (l)    Undertakers and others, on entering and while in the cemetery, will
be under the control and subject to the direction of the Board or its
designees.
(Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
963.02 RULES REGARDING GROUNDS.
   (a)    No person shall wound, kill or capture any bird or animal in the
cemetery or remove the young of any animal or the eggs of any bird.
   (b)    Children may be excluded from the cemetery at any time unless
accompanied by an adult who will be responsible for their conduct.
   (c)    No person shall pluck any plants, whether cultivated or wild,
unnecessarily disturb birds or animals, break or injure any tree or shrub, mar
any monument or landmark or in any way deface cemetery grounds.
   (d)    No person shall sit or stand upon any monument.
   (e)    No advertising of any form is allowed on cemetery grounds.
   (f)    No dogs are allowed inside the cemetery.
   (g)    No person shall discharge firearms in the cemetery except for
military funerals or Memorial Day exercises.
   (h)    The cemetery grounds are closed to everyone except employees and
other authorized persons during the hours of darkness. Violators of this
provision are subject to arrest and prosecution.
   (i)    Any person acting in a boisterous or loud manner or in any way
improper to the sanctity of the grounds may be expelled by the Board of
Cemetery Trustees or its designee.
   (j)    All persons are reminded that the grounds are sacredly devoted to the
burial of the dead and that the provisions and penalties of the law will be
strictly enforced to keep it thus.
(Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
963.03 PLANTINGS.
   No person shall plant any plants of any kind in the walkways of the
cemetery; and, although plants may be planted behind headstones, no flower
wrappers, containers or any other related materials shall be left in the
cemetery. Any plants discovered to be within the walkways shall be removed
without notice.
(Ord. 13-012. Passed 4-17-13.)
963.04 FOUNDATIONS FOR MONUMENTS.
   (a)    No monument or headstone shall be set without a foundation first
being made. Foundations shall be furnished flush with the ground level in all
parts of the cemetery.
   (b)    Foundations for all monuments and markers shall be at least four feet
deep.
   (c)    Due to the additional work of preparing for Memorial Day, orders for
foundations may be refused after May 1.
   (d)    All foundations shall have the approval of the Board of Cemetery
Trustees.
(Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
   (e)    Foundations will be poured when the Cemetery Sexton has eight or more
to pour.
(Res. R-98-045. Passed 10-21-98.)
   (f)   Every grave site shall be limited to one (1) foundation.
(Ord. 0-15-084. Passed 12-16-15.)
963.05  PLACEMENT OF HEADSTONES AND MONUMENTS.
   (a)    No monument or headstone shall be erected or placed in the cemetery
unless specifications, plans and location have been first submitted to and
approved by the Board of Cemetery Trustees. All applications shall be filed at
the Clerk-Treasurer's office.
   (b)    The Board may inspect the setting of any monument or headstone, and,
if improperly done, may order the resetting of the same.
   (c)    After a monument or headstone has been placed in the cemetery, it may
not be removed without permission of the Board.
   (d)    Monuments or markers with porcelain or other photographs inserted, or
of a grotesque, freakish or unusual design, ornamentation or size, are not
permitted.
   (e)    No monument, headstone or material used in connection with the same
shall be brought into the cemetery on Sundays or general holidays, and all work
thereon shall be done during cemetery working hours.
   (f)    Boxing, crating and packing materials and all other debris brought in
by a stone contractor shall be removed and the completed work shall be cleaned
before leaving the job.
(Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
   (g)    No pebbles, stones or bark is permitted around monuments.
(Res. R-98-045. Passed 10-21-98.)
963.06  INTERMENTS.
   (a)    The number of interments which may be properly made on a lot shall be
definitely fixed at the time of purchase, and no more will be permitted. In
order that uniformity may be sustained, the Board of Cemetery Trustees will
determine the location of graves on a lot.
   (b)    Only one body will be allowed in a grave except by special permission
of cemetery authorities.
   (c)    Interments on Sundays or general holidays are not permitted, except
when ordered by the Board of Health. No interment may be made unless the body
is accompanied by a burial permit (usually procured by the undertaker).
   (d)    No body except that of a human being may be interred in the cemetery.
   (e)    Concrete vaults are the only type permitted in Eastlake Cemetery.
   (f)    Except in the case of an emergency, thirty-six hours notice,
excluding Sundays and holidays, is required for the preparation of a grave.
   (g)    Interment charges are due and payable when the order is given and
include opening and closing of the grave only.
   (h)    All funeral processions within the cemetery will be under the
exclusive control of the Board of Cemetery Trustees or its agents.
(Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
963.07 DISINTERMENTS.
   (a)    Disinterments will be made upon court order. Permission to make
disinterments not ordered by the court will be given upon written order of the
lot owner, or the surviving spouse, child, if of legal age, or parent, of the
deceased (in the order stated), provided that such disinterment is not made for
profit or other reasons considered improper by cemetery authorities.
   (b)    No disinterment will be made until all State regulations and all
rules of the local health authorities have been complied with.
   (c)    If the relocation of the remains of a deceased person is deemed
advisable by cemetery authorities, such relocation may be made by the Board of
Cemetery Trustees and its assistants upon court order or upon written
permission given by the nearest surviving relative.
   (d)    If any single grave is vacated and the body removed therefrom, the
ground shall revert to the cemetery.
(Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
   (e)    The Clerk-Treasurer shall collect a fee for the disinterment of
cremations, stillborns and infants within the Village at the sum of three
hundred dollars ($300.00) per disinterment along with a sum representing fifty
dollars ($50.00) per hour for the Village Street Department services- related
to said disinterment.
(Res. R-02-040. Passed 8-5-02.)
963.08 LOTS.
   (a)    The purchase of lots shall be arranged through the Board of Cemetery
Trustees or its authorized representative, who will show the lots which are for
sale.
   (b)    When a section of the cemetery has been platted and prepared for
sale, the price of lots as fixed by the cemetery authorities shall be shown on
the plats, and no special price below such established rate will be allowed.
 
   (c)    The deed to a lot conveys only burial rights; the title to the land
remains in the Village.
   (d)    In general, all lot sales are for cash and the bill is payable at the
time of purchase.
   (e)    Single graves shall be sold for cash, payable before the interment is
made.
   (f)    No monument or marker of any kind, nor any foundation, shall be
erected upon any lot until the purchase price of the lot is fully paid.
   (g)    As the deed to a lot conveys only the right of burial therein, the
cemetery authorities retain control and supervision of all lots which have been
sold. The Board or its designee shall enter upon any lot and prohibit, modify
or remove any structure, object, adornment or improvements on such lot which
may have been placed thereon in violation of cemetery rules or which may be
considered, in the Board's judgment, to be objectionable or injurious to the
lot, to adjoining lots or to the general appearance of the cemetery.
(Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
963.09 TRAFFIC RULES.
   (a)    Entrance to the cemetery shall be made only by the walks and drives
maintained by the cemetery for this purpose.
   (b)    No person shall use the walks and drives in the cemetery as
thoroughfares or public highways. Motorcycles will not be permitted in the
cemetery, except as escorts.
   (c)    No person shall drive over the lawns or on the walks under any
pretense whatever, and where damage occurs therefrom, the driver of the vehicle
shall make good such damage.
   (d)    The speed of vehicles is limited to five miles per hour.
   (e)    Visitors on foot have the primary use of the drives, and vehicle
drivers shall respect this right by careful driving and strict adherence to
rules.
   (f)    Visitors are reminded that unnecessary use of cemetery drives entails
a large expense upon the cemetery for their maintenance. The privilege to drive
thereon should not be abused.
   (g)    Customary traffic rules and rules of the road are herewith made
applicable to the use of cemetery drives and walks.
(Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
963.10 ENFORCEMENT; STATUTORY EXTRACTS.
   (a)    The Board of Cemetery Trustees and/or its employees shall be charged
with the enforcement of all rules and regulations adopted by Council.
   (b)    The following extracts are from the Ohio Revised Code and are hereby
made a part hereof:
      (1)    Ohio R.C. 1721.07 "Burial lots sold by a cemetery shall be used
for the sole purpose of interments and shall be subject to the rules prescribed
by the cemetery."
      (2)    Ohio R.C. 1721.07 "A cemetery may adopt rules and regulations for
disposing of and conveying burial lots."
      (3)    Ohio R.C. 1721.09 "A cemetery may prescribe rules for enclosing
and adorning lots and for erecting monuments in the cemetery and may prohibit
any use, division, improvement or adornment of a lot which they deem to be
improper."
       (4)    Ohio R.C. 1721.19 "Watchmen or agents of a cemetery may arrest on
view a person found violating this section."
         (Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
963.11 CHARGES AND FEES.
   A current list of fees and charges may be obtained from the Clerk-Treasurer.
The charge for all work is payable in advance.
(Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
963.12  SUGGESTIONS TO LOT OWNERS.
   (a)    To avoid mistakes in the arrangement and management of cemetery lots,
cemetery officials should be consulted by the lot owner.
   (b)    Cemetery rules have been formulated, after due consideration and long
experience, for the benefit and guidance of lot owners, and it is expected that
they will be duly appreciated and complied with. We must meet on common ground
and expect all to conform to established customs in cemetery matters.
   (c)    Lot owners should lend their assistance in preserving the neatness
and careful keeping of the grounds, remembering that whatever is beneficial to
the appearance of the cemetery in general is of interest to a lot owner.
(Ord. 1024. Passed 6-22-72.)
963.13 INDIGENT BURIAL POLICY.
   (a)   When these five (5) factors are present, the body of the dead person
must be disposed of by the appropriate governmental entity as follows:
      (1)   If the person was a legal resident of the county, the proper
officers of the Village in which the body was found, shall cause it to be
buried at the expense of the Village in which he had a legal residence at the
time of his death.
      (2)   If the person had a legal residence in any other county of the
state at the time of his death, the superintendent of the county home of the
county in which such body was found shall cause it to be buried at the expense
of the appropriate governmental entity in which he had a legal residence at the
time of his death.
      (3)   If the person was an inmate of a correctional institution of the
county or a patient or resident of a benevolent institution of the county, had
no legal residence in the state, or his legal residence is unknown, the
superintendent shall cause him to be buried at the expense of the county.
   (b)   The policy of the Village for indigent burials is that the deceased
must be cremated and the Village will pay up to $750 for cremation, burial or
cremains, an urn and a grave marker.
(Ord. 12-011. Passed 5-7-12.)
963.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for each offense. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.

1101.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established in and for the Village an administrative board
to be known as the Planning Commission.
(Ord. 265. Passed 8-4-47.)
1101.02 COMPOSITION; TERMS OF OFFICE; COMPENSATION.
   The Planning Commission shall consist of the Mayor, one member of Council,
who shall be selected by Council to serve for the remainder of his or her term
as a member of Council, and three citizens to be appointed by the Mayor for
terms of six years each. All members of the Commission shall serve without
compensation.
(Ord. 265. Passed 8-4-47.)
1101.03 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)    The powers and duties of the Planning Commission shall be to make
recommendations for the general location, character and extent of streets,
alleys and other public ways, bridges, culverts, subways, parks, playgrounds
and other public grounds; for the general location of public buildings and
other public property, public utilities and terminals, whether publicly or
privately owned or operated; and for the removal, relocation, widening,
narrowing, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of such public
ways, bridges, culverts, subways, playgrounds and other public grounds,
utilities and terminals.
   (b)    The Commission shall formulate a general plan for the future
development of the Village with respect to the construction of new buildings
and the remodeling or improvement of existing buildings. The purpose of such
general plan shall be to prevent the erection of new buildings and the
remodeling, improvement or alteration of existing buildings in such a manner as
would result in the creation of a nuisance or an unsightly condition which
would, in the judgment of the Commission, detract from the value of adjoining
or nearby property, or be detrimental to the general welfare of the residents
of the Village.
(Ord. 265. Passed 8-4-47.)

   EDITOR'S NOTE: A Comprehensive Development Plan for the Village was adopted
by Council on August 6, 1979. Copies are on file in the Municipal Building for
examination by interested persons.
   There are no sections in Chapter
1105. This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross references
and any future legislation.

CHAPTER 1111
General Provisions and Definitions
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Village contracts with the County Planning Commission for
the administration of its Subdivision Regulations. Copies of the latest
relevant legislation may be obtained, at cost, from the Clerk-Treasurer.
1111.01    Short title.
1111.02    Objectives.
1111.03    Interested governmental bodies and officers.
1111.04    Jurisdiction.
1111.05    Relation to other laws; conflicts.

1111.07    Amendments.
